questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Adenolymphoma:

  • Warthin's tumor is also known as adenolymphoma. It's a benign tumor that most commonly occurs in the parotid gland, which is a salivary gland located in the cheek. It's characterized by its unique histological appearance, with cystic spaces and papillary projections lined by double-layered oncocytic epithelial cells and lymphoid stroma.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Pleomorphic Adenoma: Pleomorphic adenoma is another type of salivary gland tumor. It is the most common type of salivary gland tumor, but it is distinct from Warthin's tumor. Pleomorphic adenoma is characterized by a mixture of epithelial and myoepithelial cells in a chondromyxoid stroma.

Option C - Mucoepidermoid Carcinoma: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is a malignant salivary gland tumor. It is not synonymous with Warthin's tumor. Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is characterized by a combination of mucous-secreting, epidermoid (squamous), and intermediate cells. It is one of the most common malignant salivary gland tumors.

Option D - Acinic Cell Carcinoma: Acinic cell carcinoma is another type of malignant salivary gland tumor. It is characterized by the presence of acinar cells, which produce serous (watery) secretions. It is not the same as Warthin's tumor.

questions.text: Which of the following features is not observed in pleomorphic adenoma?
questions.solution:
Perineural invasion is not observed in pleomorphic adenoma, as it is a benign tumour. Perineural invasion occurs in carcinoma ex pleomorphic adenoma, a malignant transformation of pleomorphic adenoma.

 

Pleomorphic Adenoma:

  • Most common salivary gland neoplasm: Represents ~60% of parotid tumours, less common in submandibular and minor salivary glands.
  • Benign tumour: Composed of ductal (epithelial), myoepithelial, and mesenchymal cells (also called mixed tumour).
  • Risk factors: Radiation exposure increases risk. Chromosomal rearrangements, including overexpression of PLAG1 and mutations in HMGA2, are commonly associated.
  • Clinical presentation: Painless, slow-growing, mobile, discrete masses, usually in the parotid, submandibular, or buccal cavity.
  • Recurrence: 4% recurrence rate after parotidectomy; 25% after simple enucleation due to tumour extension beyond the capsule.
  • Malignant transformation: Occurs more often with the age of the lesion. 2% of tumours present <5 years develop malignancy; 10% present >15 years develop malignancy, usually adenocarcinomas or undifferentiated carcinomas.
  • Aggressive cancers: If malignant transformation occurs, cancers are highly infiltrative, with a 30-50% mortality rate at 5 years.
  • Morphology:
    • Size: Typically rounded, well-demarcated masses <6 cm.
    • Histological features: Heterogeneous morphology with ductal, acinar, tubule-like structures, and myoepithelial cells (Option A). Background of myxoid, hyaline, and chondroid stroma (Option C) (cartilage-like areas). Rare bone foci. No significant epithelial dysplasia or mitotic activity.
    • Tumour behaviour: Similar clinical course regardless of whether epithelial or mesenchymal elements dominate.
    • Keratin pearls (Option B): While rare, keratin pearls can occasionally be observed in pleomorphic adenoma, especially when there is squamous metaplasia within the tumour.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with dry eyes and dry mouth. Laboratory tests reveal positive anti-Ro (SSA) and anti-La (SSB) antibodies. What is the most likely underlying pathological mechanism?

choices.text: Destruction of exocrine glands by neutrophils
Lymphocytic infiltration and destruction of salivary and lacrimal glands
Deposition of amyloid in salivary glands

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Lymphocytic infiltration and destruction of salivary and lacrimal glands

Explanation:

  • This presentation is classic for Sjögren’s syndrome, an autoimmune disorder characterised by chronic lymphocytic infiltration of the salivary and lacrimal glands, leading to xerostomia (dry mouth) and keratoconjunctivitis sicca (dry eyes).
  • The condition is most common in middle-aged women and is associated with anti-Ro (SSA) and anti-La (SSB) autoantibodies.

Pathophysiology

  • Epithelial cells aS active players. Salivary/lacrimal epithelial cells (the target tissue) can act like antigen-presenting cells under stress or after viral/other triggers. They upregulate type I interferons, express costimulatory molecules and release chemokines that recruit lymphocytes.
  • Autoantigen exposure. Apoptosis or other epithelial injury exposes intracellular ribonucleoproteins (Ro/SSA, La/SSB) to the immune system, promoting an autoimmune response.
  • T-cell-driven inflammation. Early lesions are dominated by CD4⁺ T cells that home to the glands and cause inflammation and cytokine release (TH1/TH17 pathways are implicated).
  • B-cell activation & ectopic germinal centres. Chronic inflammation induces local B-cell activation, formation of ectopic germinal–centre–like structures within glands, and production of autoantibodies (anti-Ro/SSA, anti-La/SSB, rheumatoid factor). Elevated BAFF (B-cell activating factor) supports B-cell survival.
  • Structural loss of secretory tissue. Progressive acinar atrophy, ductal dilation and replacement by lymphoid infiltrates/fibrosis → functional loss of saliva and tears.

Incorrect Options:

Destruction of exocrine glands by neutrophils (Option A): is more typical of suppurative infections, not autoimmune Sjögren’s.

IgE-mediated hypersensitivity reaction (Option B): occurs in allergies and anaphylaxis, not in this chronic autoimmune process.

Deposition of amyloid in salivary glands (Option D): can occur in systemic amyloidosis, but is not the main mechanism in Sjögren’s syndrome.
